title: Quiz 25: Midwifery & Obstetrics I
topicName: NCK Paper 1 Anatomy and Physiology Questions

questions.question: A pregnant woman presents with severe abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding at 8 weeks gestation. On examination, the cervix is closed. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Severe pain at 8 weeks suggests ectopic pregnancy. While threatened abortion presents with bleeding and a closed cervix, the pain is usually mild or cramping, not severe.
questions.hint: Severe pain in the first trimester is a red flag for a tubal pregnancy.

questions.question: A pregnant woman presents with painless, bright red vaginal bleeding at 34 weeks gestation. On examination, the cervix is found to be closed. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Painless bright red bleeding in the third trimester is the hallmark sign of Placenta Previa.
questions.hint: Bleeding late in pregnancy without pain.

questions.question: A pregnant woman presents with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain and dark red vaginal bleeding at 28 weeks gestation. On examination, the uterus is tender, and the fundus feels firm. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Painful dark red bleeding with a rigid ('board-like') and tender uterus is characteristic of Placental Abruption.
questions.hint: Painful bleeding with a hard uterus.

questions.question: A pregnant woman presents with severe abdominal pain and syncope at 6 weeks gestation. On examination, she has signs of hypovolemic shock. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Ruptured ectopic pregnancy is a medical emergency causing internal bleeding, shock, and syncope in early pregnancy.
questions.hint: Fainting and shock in early pregnancy.

questions.question: A pregnant woman presents with vaginal bleeding and passage of tissue at 10 weeks gestation. On examination, the cervix is dilated, and products of conception are visualized in the cervical os. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation: When the cervix is open and products of conception are visualized in the canal but have not fully passed, it is an incomplete abortion.
questions.hint: The process has started (open cervix) but is not finished (tissue remains).

questions.question: A pregnant woman presents with severe abdominal pain and passage of tissue at 12 weeks gestation. On examination, the cervix is partially dilated, and products of conception are protruding through the cervical os. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Tissue protruding through the os with partial dilation confirms an incomplete abortion.
questions.hint: Tissue is stuck in the doorway (cervix).

questions.question: A pregnant woman presents with vaginal bleeding and crampy abdominal pain at 22 weeks gestation. On examination, the cervix is dilated, and the amniotic sac is visible at the cervical os. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Painless (or mild cramping) dilation in the second trimester with bulging membranes is characteristic of Cervical Insufficiency (Incompetent Cervix).
questions.hint: The cervix opens prematurely in the second trimester without strong labor.

questions.question: A pregnant woman presents with a history of recurrent pregnancy losses in the second trimester. On examination, the cervix is dilated, and uterine contractions are absent. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Recurrent second-trimester loss with painless dilation is the classic presentation of cervical incompetence.
questions.hint: Recurring loss around 20 weeks due to a weak cervix.

questions.question: A pregnant woman presents with recurrent episodes of severe abdominal pain, bloating, and constipation. On examination, an abdominal mass is palpable, and bowel sounds are diminished. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation: An adnexal mass (cyst) causing torsion can present with severe pain and GI symptoms like nausea/vomiting/constipation, mimicking obstruction.
questions.hint: A twisted ovary can feel like a bowel obstruction.

questions.question: A pregnant woman presents with lower abdominal pain, fever, and vaginal discharge. On examination, cervical motion tenderness and bilateral adnexal tenderness are noted. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Cervical motion tenderness (Chandelier sign), fever, and discharge are the classic triad for PID.
questions.hint: Infection of the reproductive tract causing the 'Chandelier sign'.

questions.question: A pregnant woman presents with severe lower abdominal pain, fever, and vaginal discharge. On examination, cervical motion tenderness and adnexal tenderness are noted, along with bilateral adnexal masses. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Bilateral masses in the context of PID symptoms suggest Tubo-Ovarian Abscesses (TOA).
questions.hint: Severe PID leading to abscesses on both sides.

questions.question: A pregnant woman presents with severe lower abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. On examination, cervical motion tenderness and unilateral adnexal tenderness are noted, along with an adnexal mass on the affected side. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Unilateral mass and pain with bleeding in early pregnancy is Ectopic Pregnancy until proven otherwise.
questions.hint: Mass on ONE side + Bleeding + Pain.

questions.question: A pregnant woman presents with sudden onset of severe lower abdominal pain and syncope. On examination, she appears pale, and her abdomen is distended and tense. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Syncope and a distended, tense abdomen (hemoperitoneum) suggest a ruptured ectopic pregnancy causing internal bleeding.
questions.hint: Fainting + Tense abdomen = Internal bleeding from a rupture.

questions.question: A pregnant woman presents with fever, chills, and abdominal pain localized to the right lower quadrant. On examination, she has rebound tenderness and guarding. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation: RLQ pain + Fever + Rebound tenderness is the classic presentation of Appendicitis.
questions.hint: Pain in the lower right side with fever.

questions.question: A pregnant woman presents with fever, chills, and abdominal pain localized to the right upper quadrant. On examination, she has tenderness in the right upper abdomen and a positive Murphy's sign. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation: RUQ pain and a positive Murphy's sign (pain on inspiration while palpating the gallbladder) indicate Acute Cholecystitis.
questions.hint: Pain under the right ribs, often after eating.

questions.question: A pregnant woman presents with severe lower abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. On examination, she has a tender, distended abdomen. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Without gestational age context, 'lower abdominal pain' with distension (blood) and bleeding is most commonly Ectopic Pregnancy in the exam context compared to Uterine Rupture (usually labor/late term).
questions.hint: Think early pregnancy emergency.

questions.question: A pregnant woman presents with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. On examination, her abdomen is rigid, and fetal parts are palpable abdominally. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation: 'Fetal parts palpable abdominally' (outside the uterus) is the hallmark catastrophic sign of Uterine Rupture.
questions.hint: You can feel the baby directly through the belly because the uterus has torn open.

questions.question: A pregnant woman presents with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. On examination, her abdomen is rigid, and fetal parts are palpable abdominally. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Repetitive question: Uterine Rupture.
questions.hint: Fetal parts outside the uterus.

questions.question: A pregnant woman presents with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. On examination, her abdomen is rigid, and fetal parts are palpable abdominally. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Repetitive question: Uterine Rupture.
questions.hint: Fetal parts outside the uterus.

questions.question: A pregnant woman presents with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. On examination, her abdomen is rigid, and fetal parts are palpable abdominally. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Repetitive question: Uterine Rupture.
questions.hint: Fetal parts outside the uterus.

questions.question: A pregnant woman presents with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. On examination, her abdomen is rigid, and fetal parts are palpable abdominally. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Repetitive question: Uterine Rupture.
questions.hint: Fetal parts outside the uterus.

questions.question: A pregnant woman presents with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. On examination, her abdomen is rigid, and fetal parts are palpable abdominally. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Repetitive question: Uterine Rupture.
questions.hint: Fetal parts outside the uterus.

questions.question: A pregnant woman presents with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. On examination, her abdomen is rigid, and fetal parts are palpable abdominally. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Repetitive question: Uterine Rupture.
questions.hint: Fetal parts outside the uterus.

questions.question: A pregnant woman presents with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. On examination, her abdomen is rigid, and fetal parts are palpable abdominally. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Repetitive question: Uterine Rupture.
questions.hint: Fetal parts outside the uterus.

questions.question: A pregnant woman presents with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. On examination, her abdomen is rigid, and fetal parts are palpable abdominally. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Repetitive question: Uterine Rupture.
questions.hint: Fetal parts outside the uterus.

questions.question: During the active phase of labor, the nurse observes that the cervix is dilated to 6 cm and the contractions are regular, lasting 60 seconds each, occurring every 3 minutes. What action should the nurse take?

options.text: Continue to monitor the progress of labor.

questions.explanation: This describes a normal, healthy active labor pattern (regular, strong contractions with progression). No intervention is needed.
questions.hint: If labor is progressing normally, don't interfere.

questions.question: A primigravida at 39 weeks gestation presents to the labor and delivery unit with contractions every 5 minutes, lasting 45 seconds each. On examination, her cervix is dilated to 3 cm. What is the appropriate nursing intervention?

options.text: Encourage the mother to walk to facilitate labor progression.
Encourage relaxation techniques to manage pain.

questions.explanation: The patient is in the latent phase of labor (0-6 cm). Ambulation uses gravity to help the fetus descend and promotes dilation.
questions.hint: Walking helps labor progress in the early stages.

questions.question: A multiparous woman in active labor complains of back pain and pressure in her rectum. On examination, the nurse notes that the fetus is in the occiput posterior position. What nursing interventions are appropriate?

options.text: Encourage the mother to lie on her back to relieve pressure on her back.
Assist the mother into a hands-and-knees position to help rotate the fetus.
Administer intravenous opioids for pain relief.

questions.explanation: 'Back labor' is caused by the baby's head pressing against the mother's spine (Occiput Posterior). The hands-and-knees position encourages the baby to rotate anteriorly due to gravity.
questions.hint: Change position to 'all fours' to get the baby off the spine.

questions.question: A woman in active labor is experiencing prolonged rupture of membranes (>24 hours). What complication should the nurse assess for in the mother and fetus?
questions.explanation: The risk of chorioamnionitis (infection) increases significantly after 24 hours of membrane rupture.
questions.hint: Bacteria can ascend into the uterus once the protective sac is broken.

questions.question: A woman in active labor is experiencing meconium-stained amniotic fluid. What is the nurse's priority action?

options.text: Insert a urinary catheter to monitor urine output.

questions.explanation: Meconium staining poses a risk for Meconium Aspiration Syndrome. A skilled resuscitation team must be present at birth to manage the airway if the infant is not vigorous.
questions.hint: Prepare for a baby who might have trouble breathing at birth.

questions.question: A primigravida at 40 weeks gestation is in active labor. The nurse notes late decelerations on the fetal monitor tracing. What action should the nurse take first?
questions.explanation: Intrauterine resuscitation starts with the least invasive, most effective maneuver: changing maternal position (usually left lateral) to improve placental perfusion.
questions.hint: Turn the patient to improve blood flow.

questions.question: A woman in active labor requests pain relief. Which pharmacological option is safe and effective for pain management during labor?
questions.explanation: Nitrous oxide (Entonox) is a safe, self-administered inhalational analgesic. Ibuprofen is contraindicated; Morphine risks respiratory depression close to delivery.
questions.hint: Gas and air.

questions.question: A woman in active labor is receiving an epidural analgesic for pain relief. What assessment findings indicate a potential complication of epidural analgesia?
questions.explanation: Epidurals cause sympathetic blockade, resulting in vasodilation and a drop in blood pressure (hypotension), which can affect fetal perfusion.
questions.hint: The blood vessels dilate, causing pressure to drop.

questions.question: A woman in active labor is receiving intravenous oxytocin for labor augmentation. What nursing intervention is essential to prevent oxytocin-induced uterine hyperstimulation?

options.text: Monitor maternal vital signs every 2 hours.
Increase the oxytocin infusion rate gradually.
Encourage the mother to ambulate regularly.

questions.explanation: 'Start low, go slow' is the principle. Gradual titration prevents tachysystole (too many contractions), which can distress the fetus.
questions.hint: Don't rush the medication; titrate carefully.

questions.question: A woman in active labor requests hydrotherapy for pain relief. What is the nurse's priority action before initiating hydrotherapy?

options.text: Obtain informed consent from the mother.
Ensure that the labor room is equipped with a hydrotherapy tub.
Assess the maternal and fetal conditions for eligibility.
Review the mother's medical history for contraindications.

questions.explanation: Safety first. The nurse must ensure membranes are intact (or policy allows), FHR is stable, and there are no contraindications before allowing tub use.
questions.hint: Check if it's safe for mom and baby first.

questions.question: A woman in active labor is experiencing intense pain and requests non-pharmacological pain relief measures. What intervention should the nurse prioritize?
questions.explanation: Continuous labor support (by a nurse or doula) is proven to decrease pain perception and improve outcomes without medication.
questions.hint: Being there for the patient is the most effective non-drug tool.

questions.question: A woman in active labor is experiencing persistent occiput posterior position despite position changes. What nursing intervention is most appropriate to facilitate fetal rotation?

options.text: Encourage the mother to remain in a side-lying position.
Assist the mother into a hands-and-knees position.
Administer intravenous oxytocin to augment contractions.
Perform manual rotation of the fetus during vaginal examination.

questions.explanation: The hands-and-knees (all-fours) position uses gravity to help rotate the fetus from posterior to anterior.
questions.hint: Repetitive question: Get on hands and knees.

questions.question: A woman in active labor has a prolonged second stage with inadequate expulsive efforts. What nursing intervention is appropriate to facilitate fetal descent?

options.text: Encourage the mother to push forcefully during contractions.
Apply fundal pressure to assist with fetal descent.
Administer intravenous magnesium sulfate for uterine relaxation.

questions.explanation: Effective, coached pushing during contractions helps expulsion. Fundal pressure is contraindicated due to rupture risk.
questions.hint: Coach the mom to push when the contraction peaks.

questions.question: A woman in active labor is receiving intravenous antibiotics for group B streptococcus (GBS) prophylaxis. What maternal assessment finding indicates a potential adverse reaction to the antibiotics?
questions.explanation: Urticaria (hives) and pruritus (itching) are classic signs of an allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to antibiotics like Penicillin.
questions.hint: Itching and hives.

questions.question: A woman in active labor is receiving intravenous magnesium sulfate for the prevention of eclampsia. What maternal assessment finding indicates magnesium toxicity?
questions.explanation: Magnesium sulfate depresses the central nervous system. Signs of toxicity include loss of deep tendon reflexes (DTRs), muscle weakness, and respiratory depression.
questions.hint: Everything slows down: reflexes disappear and muscles get weak.
